title: England and Wales get another taste of the typhoon as huge rain puddles plague the Yokohama pitch
text:
England and Wales had to wade through huge puddles at the Yokohama Stadium before their World Cup semi-finals as a deluge left the pitch in a poor state.

The venue for both this weekend's semi-finals and next Saturday's final - the 72,000 seater ground - was rained on consistently for most of Friday.

It left the surface with standing water on it when the English and Welsh sides trained.

An England player runs through a massive puddle on the pitch during Friday's captain's run

England's Lewis Ludlam pictured during the session at The International Stadium in Yokohama

The squads had to jump over a huge body of water to make it to the pitch, and players were seen chucking balls into the turf that did not bounce at all due to the soggy conditions.

It did not deter Welsh forwards coach Robin McBryde, though, who took his shoes and socks off to walk around the field bare-footed.

By the time Wales finished their session the pitch had drained, and there was no standing water left on the surface.

England bore the worst of the weather and were almost an hour delayed for their training session at the ground. They are staying 30 miles from the stadium near Tokyo's Disneyland and were stuck in traffic getting to the ground.

Manu Tuilagi passes the ball during England's final training session before the semi-final

England coach Eddie Jones grins as the rain continues to pour down in Yokohama

Despite the pitch looking waterlogged, there aren't any concerns the match won't go ahead

Neal Hatley, the forwards coach said: 'The rain was a bit of a factor.

'It was about 10 minutes longer than expected so we'll have a look. The logistics have been brilliant through the whole tournament and it's not due to rain tomorrow.'

But their squad took the hindrance lightly, splashing around in the water around the ground.

New Zealand chose not to come to the stadium for their captain's run session, and the Springboks just sent their kickers along.

World Rugby are not concerned that the conditions will affect the weekend's matches.

Wales braved the conditions and went ahead with their planned training session on Friday

Neil Hatley said England will review travel plans for Saturday after arriving late for training

This stadium was the one where Japan played against Scotland the day after Typhoon Hagibis ripped through the capital - so it is used to coping with bad weather.

The rain is set to ease on Friday night and Saturday - when England face New Zealand - is set to be dry.

There may be a drop of rain for Wales v South Africa on Sunday, though.

If a game does have to be moved due to the weather there are contingency plans.

Sportsmail understands the Tokyo Stadium 12 miles away would be an alternative venue in the highly unlikely event a match had to be moved.
description: WILL KELLEHER IN YOKOHAMA: England and Wales had to wade through huge puddles at the Yokohama Stadium before their World Cup semi-finals as a deluge left the pitch in a poor state.
